subject: Re: [junit] Test Everything, No Matter How Simple
msgSnippet: ... That s not very realistic, is it? In reality, we need to make compromises all the time and decide what part of our code we re not going to write tests for,
messageBody:
On 8/22/06, Elliotte Harold <elharo@...> wrote:
>
> Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
>
> > So you're recommending 100% code coverage?
> >
>
> Yes.


That's not very realistic, is it?

In reality, we need to make compromises all the time and decide what part of
our code we're not going to write tests for, so in effect, there *is* code
that is too simple to be tested.

More specifically in this article, I'm recommending that when you
> find a bug, you write a test for it first, even if the fix is obvious.
> The class in question had 100% code coverage before the bug was noticed.
> 100% code coverage is practically a necessary but not sufficient
> condition for bug free code.


100% code coverage is not just impossible to obtain and maintain, it's also
deceptive and can make you think you are exercising your code in all
possible ways. Which is, of course, never true.

If I have to choose between bumping my code coverage from 90% to 91% and
writing a test that will exercise a documented feature, I will pick the
latter any day.

--
Cédric
http://testng.org
